questions.text: You're a nurse working in the Emergency Room one night when a mother and child come in. The mother claims the child is feeling ill, eating poorly, has no energy, and is suffering from diarrhea over the course of two days. Over the counter medication has not helped, and the mother was encouraged by a friend to bring the child to the hospital.

asset.alt: Drawing of a nurse pushing a stretcher with patient.

questions.text: After reviewing the patient's chart, what is your next reasonable step?

answers.text: Offer Mom some coffee.

options.feedback: While a nice thing to do, this is not the best choice at this time. Your focus should be on the child.

answers.text: Interview the Mom and child about the history of his illness and perform an initial examination.
Time is short! Just perform an initial examination.

questions.text: You collect the results of your examination, as well as the history of the child's illness provided by the mother. Symptoms include consistent diarrhea, lethargy, rapid breathing, dry lips, and refuses to drink fluids. Through your interview with the mother, you also learn that the child has not been urinating, can't produce tears, and prior to becoming ill, spent the day outside on a hot day and didn't drink much water.
After reviewing your findings, you're ready to make a nursing diagnosis. The symptoms could be related to dehydration, influenza (the flu), or hyperglycemia (high blood sugar). What do you decide?

asset.alt: Drawing of a doctor reviewing documents.

answers.text: These symptoms strongly suggest Dehydration.
I think the child has Hyperglycemia.
The child could have Influenza.

questions.text: Your next step is to contact the Healthcare Provider on-staff for orders. In a hospital setting, who might this be (e.g., a doctor, nurse, etc)?

answers.text: [Unmatched Response]

options.feedback: Incorrect. This individual cannot issue orders or write a prescription. HCP's include doctors, physicians assistants, or nurse practitioners.

answers.text: Doctor, Nurse Practitioner, NP, Physicians Assistant, PA, APRN

questions.text: You're ready to contact the Healthcare Provider (HCP) for orders based on the child's symptoms and your diagnosis of dehydration. Which symptoms do you consider the most important?

answers.text: I think the child's diarrhea, lack of urination, and inability to drink fluids are the most important symptoms.

options.feedback: Correct. All of these are fairly clear signs of dehydration.

answers.text: I think the child's temperature (37.2 C), dry lips, and fatigue are the most important symptoms.

options.feedback: Incorrect. The temperature is normal, but the dry lips and fatigue are inconclusive of dehydration.

questions.text: The Healthcare Provider has returned with orders based on your diagnosis and the child's symptoms. You begin IV treatment to restore the child's fluids, and after collecting blood and urine samples for testing, begin to let the child recover.

asset.alt: Drawing of a maternal figure comforting a sick patient in bed.

questions.text: Several hours later, the child is feeling greatly improved. He sits up and asks for a drink and appears in good health. With hospital care completed, what's the next step?

answers.text: As soon as the paperwork is completed, the mother can take the child home.

options.feedback: Not quite! You should brief the mother on a home care plan to make sure the child stays healthy.

answers.text: Before leaving, the mother should be briefed on a home care plan to ensure the child remains in good health.

options.feedback: Good! A home care plan will ensure the child will remain properly hydrated in the near future.

questions.text: Great work! You've helped the child recover and successfully diagnosed and treated his dehydration. The mother thanks you earnestly as they leave.

asset.alt: A photograph of congratulatory balloons in a hospital being held by someone just out of frame.

questions.text: Excellent work! You've helped the child recover and successfully diagnosed and treated his dehydration. The mother thanks you earnestly as they leave.

asset.alt: A photograph of congratulatory balloons in a hospital being held by someone just out of frame.

questions.text: Despite providing the wrong symptoms, the Healthcare Provider gives you orders after looking at the patient's chart and your diagnosis. You begin IV treatment to restore the child's fluids, and after collecting blood and urine samples for testing, begin to let the child recover.

asset.alt: Drawing of a maternal figure comforting a sick patient in bed.

questions.text: Several hours later, the child is feeling greatly improved. He sits up and asks for a drink and appears in good health. With hospital care completed, what's the next step?

answers.text: As soon as the paperwork is completed, the mother can take the child home.

options.feedback: Not quite! You should brief the mother on a home care plan to make sure the child stays healthy.

answers.text: Before leaving, the mother should be briefed on a home care plan to ensure the child remains in good health.

options.feedback: Good! A home care plan will ensure the child will remain properly hydrated in the near future.

questions.text: Good job! While flustering the Healthcare Provider and hospital staff with a few mistakes, you've helped the child recover and successfully diagnosed and treated his dehydration. The mother thanks you earnestly as they leave.

asset.alt: A photograph of congratulatory balloons in a hospital being held by someone just out of frame.

questions.text: Nice job! Despite some missteps, you've helped the child recover and successfully diagnosed and treated his dehydration. The mother thanks you earnestly as they leave.

asset.alt: A photograph of congratulatory balloons in a hospital being held by someone just out of frame.

questions.text: Your next step is to contact the Healthcare Provider on-staff for orders. In a hospital setting, who might this be (e.g., a doctor, nurse, etc)?

answers.text: [Unmatched Response]

options.feedback: Incorrect. This individual cannot issue orders or write a prescription. HCP's include doctors, physicians assistants, or nurse practitioners.

answers.text: Doctor, Nurse practitioner, NP, Physicians Assistant, PA, APRN

options.feedback: Correct. This individual can issue orders and write prescriptions.

questions.text: After reviewing the child's symptoms, the Healthcare Provider rejects your diagnosis of hyperglycemia! You're provided with two options: additional examination to confirm high blood sugar, or to reconsider your diagnosis. What do you choose?

answers.text: The HCP is wrong! I know it's hyperglycemia. The child needs treatment immediately!
I'm still pretty sure it's hyperglycemia - let's run additional tests to see.
I think hyperglycemia might be the wrong diagnosis. Let me reconsider what the child has.

questions.text: The Healthcare Provider balks at your decision to go ahead and perform treatment despite their refusal. You're immediately ordered to leave the emergency room and pack your things - time to find a new job!
You've decided to run additional assessments to confirm your diagnosis of hyperglycemia in the child. What kind of examination do you decide to perform?

answers.text: Let's check the child's electrolytes - especially potassium.
I want to check the child's blood glucose level.
I think we should re-check respiration and blood pressure.

questions.text: The Healthcare Provider agrees with your decision to check the child's blood glucose level. The results are normal, and it's determined the child does not have hyperglycemia. The HCP suggests you reexamine the symptoms and select a different diagnosis.

asset.alt: A drawing of a doctor inspecting the tip of a syringe.

questions.text: The Healthcare Provider agrees with your decision to check the child's electrolytes. After receiving the results, it's determined the child does not have hyperglycemia. The HCP suggests you reexamine the symptoms and select a different diagnosis.

asset.alt: A drawing of a doctor inspecting the tip of a syringe.

questions.text: The Healthcare Provider denies your recommendation to check the child's blood pressure and respiration again - you clearly don't know what you're doing, they say. You're immediately given the order to pack your things and leave!
Your next step is to contact the Healthcare Provider on-staff for orders. In a hospital setting, who might this be (e.g., a doctor, nurse, etc)?

answers.text: [Unmatched Response]

options.feedback: Incorrect. This individual cannot issue orders or write a prescription. HCP's include doctors, physicians assistants, or nurse practitioners.

answers.text: Doctor, Nurse practitioner, NP, Physicians Assistant, PA, APRN

options.feedback: Correct. This individual can issue orders and write prescriptions.

questions.text: After reviewing the child's symptoms, the Healthcare Provider rejects your diagnosis of Influenza! Before going further, they point to the patient chart and demand to know what led you to believe the child has the flu.
Which part of the chart do you think best provides a case for influenza?

asset.alt: An example medical chart with symptoms that include shallow and rapid respiration, lethargy and irritability, dry lips, bowel sounds, and inability to urinate or take fluids.

answers.text: The patient's temperature
The patient cannot urinate and won't take fluids
The patient is lethargic

questions.text: The Healthcare Provider notes that the patient's temperature - 37 degrees Celsius, or 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit - is normal! The chart is taken away from you and you're asked to leave the emergency room and collect your things.
The Healthcare Provider calmly informs you that none of these symptoms are related to the flu. You're asked to leave the emergency room and collect your things.
While lethargy is also a sign of influenza, the Healthcare Provider is not convinced the child has influenza. They suggest you review the symptoms and select a different diagnosis.

You collect the results of your examination, as well as the history of the child's illness provided by the mother. Symptoms include consistent diarrhea, lethargy, rapid breathing, dry lips, and refusal to drink fluids.
